Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research in IPY: Abrupt Environmental Change in the Larsen Ice Shelf System, a Multidisciplinary Approach - Marine Ecosystems.
Award.AbstractNarration:
0732983 - Vernet, Maria - Scripps Institute of Oceanography
0732450 - Van Dover, Cindy - Duke University
0732711 - Smith, Craig - University of Hawaii
0732917 - McCormick, Michael - Hamilton College

Collaborative Research in IPY: Abrupt Environmental Change in the
Larsen Ice Shelf System, a Multidisciplinary Approach - Marine
Ecosystems.

A profound transformation in ecosystem structure and function is occurring in coastal waters of the western Weddell Sea, with the collapse of the Larsen B ice shelf. This transformation appears to be yielding a redistribution of energy flow between chemoautotrophic and photosynthetic production, and to be causing the rapid demise of the extraordinary seep ecosystem discovered beneath the ice shelf. This event provides an ideal opportunity to examine fundamental aspects of ecosystem transition associated with climate change. We propose to test the following hypotheses to elucidate the transformations occurring in marine ecosystems as a consequence of the Larsen B collapse: (1) The biogeographic isolation and sub-ice shelf setting of the Larsen B seep has led to novel habitat characteristics, chemoautotrophically dependent taxa and functional adaptations. (2) Benthic communities beneath the former Larsen B ice shelf are fundamentally different from assemblages at similar depths in the Weddell sea-ice zone, and resemble oligotrophic deep-sea communities. Larsen B assemblages are undergoing rapid change. (3) The previously dark, oligotrophic waters of the Larsen B embayment now support a thriving phototrophic community, with production rates and phytoplankton composition similar to other productive areas of the Weddell Sea. To document rapid changes occurring in the Larsen B ecosystem, we will use a remotely operated vehicle, shipboard samplers, and moored sediment traps. We will characterize microbial, macrofaunal and megafaunal components of the seep community; evaluate patterns of surface productivity, export flux, and benthic faunal composition in areas previously covered by the ice shelf, and compare these areas to the open sea-ice zone. These changes will be placed within the geological, glaciological and climatological context that led to ice-shelf retreat, through companion research projects funded in concert with this effort. Together these projects will help predict the likely consequences of ice-shelf collapse to marine ecosystems in other regions of Antarctica vulnerable to climate change. The research features international collaborators from Argentina, Belgium, Canada, Germany, Spain and the United Kingdom. The broader impacts include participation of a science writer; broadcast of science segments by members of the Jim Lehrer News Hour (Public Broadcasting System); material for summer courses in environmental change; mentoring of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows; and showcasing scientific activities and findings to students and public through podcasts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Antarctic Peninsula is one of the fastest warming regions on Earth. Within the last 25 years we have witnessed the largest ice-shelf collapses in recorded history as a consequence of our changing climate (the Larsen A and B ice-shelves in 1995 and 2002, respectively). Despite surrounding more than thee quarters of the Antarctic coastline and covering one third of Antarctica’s continental shelf, sub-ice-shelf benthic habitats are among the least studied ecosystems in the world. The Larsen Ice Shelf System Antarctica (LARISSA) project, brought together an interdisciplinary team of scientists whose interests span glaciology/ice sciences, oceanography, marine and terrestrial geology, and biology to investigate the effects of ice-shelf loss on ice-ocean-ecosystem interactions in this region. In specific, the objective of our group was to document and better understand the effect of ice-shelf retreat on the benthic microbial community in the Larsen A embayment.

 Due to the exclusion of light, sub-ice shelf ecosystems are dark environments devoid of phytoplankton productivity and are thus expected to be carbon and energy starved. Following collapse of the Larsen A ice-shelf, the exposure of surface waters to direct light, brought new sources of carbon and energy in the form of algal booms that seasonally rise and decline and ultimately deliver pulses of carbon to the sea floor.  This sudden change from an organic carbon-starved to seasonally carbon-rich system, likely resulted in profound changes in sediment geochemistry and microbial community composition. To better understand the long-term effects of ice-shelf loss on the benthic microbial community and biogeochemical processes we conducted a five-station survey along a 160 km transect following the historic path of retreat of the Larsen A ice shelf. The selected stations represent a range in time since ice-shelf loss from approximately 16 years closest to shore to over 170 years at the outermost station.

Our work revealed that a few centimeters below the sediment surface the Larsen A benthic microbial communities are dominated by Thaumarchaeota, a group of archaea that play an important role in the cycling of inorganic nitrogen species. Intriguingly, most of the dominant microbial populations across much of the transect gain energy to sustain life through the oxidation of ammonia. And these ammonia-oxidizing populations change as we move off shore, with aerobic oxidation of ammonia (AOA) mediated by Thaumarchaeota dominating in the mid-transect stations and anaerobic ammonia oxidation (anammox) mediated by Planctomycetes emerging as an important process at the outer most (mid-shelf) stations. Notably, both of these populations are autotrophs (capable of fixing carbon dioxide), indicating adaptation to an environment with low organic carbon inputs as expected under an ice shelf. In contrast to the deeper sediments, surface sediments, which have been exposed to fresh inputs of organic carbon due to recent phytoplankton productivity, are enriched in heterotrophs (organisms that use organic carbon rather than carbon dioxide for cell building processes), indicating a successional process is underway between pre-breakout and post breakout communities, even 20+ years after ice-shelf loss.

The cross-shelf transect conducted during the NBP12-03 cruise provides the first detailed biogeographic survey of microbial community composition along the historic path of retreat of the Larsen A ice-shelf. The geochemical data we collected and the complementary parallel data sets being developed by our Larissa collaborators will permit us to comprehensively develop an integrated model of benthic ecosystem response to ice-shelf loss. Although we are still interpreting the results, we believe this data set has the potential to help anticipate the response of other sub-ice self benthic ecosystems to ice-shelf loss (e.g., Larsen C) on time scales of decades to centuries. Such perspectives will likely inform the work of other scientists who are investigating the ongoing effects of climate warming in the Earth’s polar regions.
